awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Density-enhanced data assimilation for hyperbolic balance laws
awd_abstract_narration:
The research addresses the urgent need to develop efficient computational tools to process the dramatically increasing amounts of observational data. Management of many complex systems (e.g., traffic) has to confront the uncertainty in both their current and future state. This uncertainty typically increases with time, leading to less accurate and useful predictions. Thus, it is important to develop practical methods for "adjusting" the probabilistic state of the system and reducing uncertainty using observational data. This approach is broadly referred to as data assimilation. We will develop novel techniques for incorporating observational data to reduce uncertainty in predictions in two particular areas  of national interest: fluid dynamics (e.g., flood forecasting) and traffic management. Both are of vital importance to sustainable development of our society.

We propose to develop a novel data assimilation framework for physical processes whose time-dynamics is described by hyperbolic conservation laws. This framework takes advantage of a kinetic representation of hyperbolic systems and, thus, availability of explicit deterministic equations for the time evolution of probability density function for dependent variables. These equations can often be derived and solved exactly, yielding explicit analytical solutions for the marginal and joint probability density functions. For systems of hyperbolic conservation laws an appropriate closure assumption is needed. Thus, the proposed framework relies on the kinetic representation, which takes the form of linear equations for joint probability density functions. Bayesian updating is utilized to incorporate observations into the prediction.

por.por_cntn:
Many physical processes are described quite accurately by evolutionary (partial) differential equations. These differential equations have high predictive power and can be used to forecasts various physical processes in the future. However, in many practical applications the current state of the system (initial conditions for the corresponding differential equation) is not known exactly. Instead, there is some uncertainty and initial conditions are known only in probabilistic sense. This uncertainty in initial conditions then propagates in time and can drastically affect the predictive power of differential equations. The main focus of this proposal is to analyze uncertainty propagation in context of various examples from evolutionary dynamics. In several papers we analyzed uncertainty propagation in various spatially-extended systems. Particular examples include underground pollution transport, information flow, fluid dynamics. We also developed (stochastic and machine learning) techniques for incorporating uncertainty in physical parameters in evolutionary models. These techniques include estimation of uncertainty in parameters and using machine learning techniques to infer randomness in the equations. This work particularly emphasizes developing reduced model and analyzing uncertainty in the dynamics of so-called coarse (or averaged) quantities. Evolutionary equations for coarse variables are highly computationally efficient, but lead to increased levels of uncertainty due to the loss of information during averaging. Current work also emphasize the balance between these two issues and suggests practical guidelines for selecting the coarsening level.

 

Several graduate students were supported by this project. One of them is a female student who already graduated in August 2020 and obtained a job in the biomedical data analysis in the US. Another student will graduate in May/August 2021. Several papers appeared or have been submitted to prominent interdisciplinary journals.
